page.title: 05Oast Houses in Kent
page.content: The first{Oast Houses}were rectangular and small (about 6m by 3m). The traditional painted white wooden{cowl was not added until much later. Early Oast Houses date from the 17th to early 18th century and early examples still exist at Woodchurch and Charing Place. After finding these models were too small, they went on to build cone Oast Houses and this is where the traditional white painted{cowl}was added. They mistakenly believed that cone Oast Houses distributed the heat more evenly. The{kiln}sloped more to the left, and sometimes the cowl fell off! Early in the 19th century they discovered that rectangular Oast Houses were just as efficient and easier to build, so they returned to this design.
